title: The Code Crackers are Cheating Ma Bell
historical_context: This article reflects the early 1990s hacking culture, particularly focusing on toll fraud and the use of technology to exploit telephone systems.
short_summary: The article discusses the rampant toll fraud in the telecommunications industry, where hackers exploit personal identification numbers to make free long-distance calls, costing companies millions. It highlights the methods used by these hackers and the challenges faced by phone companies in combating this issue.
summary:
In this article, 'The Code Crackers are Cheating Ma Bell', the author explores the widespread issue of toll fraud in the telecommunications sector, where hackers utilize personal identification numbers (PINs) to make unauthorized long-distance calls. The piece illustrates various scenarios, from inmates in California prisons to college students in Tennessee, who exploit these codes for free calls, leading to significant financial losses for phone companies, estimated at over $500 million annually. The article emphasizes the technical prowess of these hackers, who use computer programs to brute-force PINs, likening their methods to safecracking. As a result, unsuspecting customers receive exorbitant bills for calls they never made, often leading to frustration and account cancellations. 

The article also delves into the responses from telecommunications companies and law enforcement, detailing their attempts to monitor and combat this fraud. Companies like U.S. Sprint employ surveillance tactics and flag suspicious billing patterns, while the FBI conducts sweeps of electronic bulletin boards to track stolen codes. Despite these efforts, the article reveals a sense of ambivalence among the public towards the ethics of such hacking, with some rationalizing their actions against large corporations. The narrative concludes with insights from a former hacker, Dr. Strange, who reflects on the evolution of hacking from blue boxes to modern computer-based methods, highlighting the ongoing cat-and-mouse game between hackers and the telecommunications industry.
